moves.2... d6: A move that leads, if followed up properly, to a solid [albeit somewhat cramped] position for Black.
moves.3... Bg4: This move compels Black to concede a minor exchange...
moves.4. dxe5: ...after this reply, in order to avoid losing material.
moves.6. Bc4: White now has an advantage in development, and incidentally threatens the weak spot at Black's KB2.
moves.6... Nf6: Shielding the weakness from the White Q.
moves.7... b6: The fatal error. Further development was called for. 7... Q-Q2 adds valuable protection to the KBP, and even 7... B-K2 would create a flight square.
moves.8. Bxf7+: Black cannot interpose or capture, so he must move his K.
moves.8... Kd7: 8... K-K2 also falls victim to White's next move.
